timeline.bodyText: What is the relationship between these types?  Are their erased/raw types the same?  Or is there a subtyping relationship?

As described in JLS section + * 4.10.2 Subtyping among Class and Interface Types, a declared type is considered a supertype + * of another declared type only if all of the type arguments of the declared type "contain" the + * corresponding type arguments of the subtype. + * + * @param inside a possibly-contained type + * @param outside a possibly-containing type

timeline.bodyText: I usually expect to see a check of a cache at the beginning of the routine.  Should it be moved there, or is there a reason that it needs to appear after other logic?

replies.bodyText: I don't think so.  This method is called for unbound wildcards and also captured type variables.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: I wasn't sure what "BoundType" means.  It sounds like it's containment by the bound type itself, by it's really containment within the bounds.  Maybe isContainedByBoundedType or isContainedWithinBounds or the like?
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: "they should be equal":  I'm not sure whether this is describing an application invariant that is true whenever control reaches this line, or it is describing a test that will be performed later in the routine.  Could you rewrite to resolve the ambiguity?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
"Checks that" could mean that the method throws an exception or reports an error.
Or, "checks that" could indicate the method's return value.
Could you resolve the ambiguity?
I think that all the visit methods are returning a boolean value indicating whether the method's arguments are in a subtyping relationship.  It would be good to document that in the class Javadoc.

timeline.bodyText: Please make this comment more descriptive.

-   * A helper class for visitDeclared_Declared. There are subtypes of DefaultTypeHierarchy that need
-   * to customize the handling of type arguments. This method provides a convenient extension point.
+   * Checks that the type arguments in {@code supertype} contain the type arguments in {@code
+   * subtype}. See {@link #isContainedBy} for an explanation of containment.

timeline.bodyText:
I think this is only handling the 3rd bullet point of that paragraph.  Does it actually handle more?
Nit: I would change "JLS" to "JLS 11" in case later editions rewrite the section.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I answered this in this comment.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: I am a bit confused by this code.  The 5th paragraph says that -- after capture conversion -- one should do a regular subtyping test.  Is this an optimization, because the subtyping test would boil down to isContainedMany?  Or is there another reason we need to diverge from the JLS text?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
Here's that section in the JLS.  I've numbered the paragraphs and used letters for the bullet points.

4.) Given a generic type declaration C<F1,...,Fn> (n > 0), the direct supertypes of the parameterized type C<T1,...,Tn>, where Ti (1 ≤ i ≤ n) is a type, are all of the following:
A.) D<U1 θ,...,Uk θ>, where D<U1,...,Uk> is a generic type which is a direct supertype of the generic type C<F1,...,Fn> and θ is the substitution [F1:=T1,...,Fn:=Tn].
B.) C<S1,...,Sn>, where Si contains Ti (1 ≤ i ≤ n) (§4.5.1).
C.) The type Object, if C<F1,...,Fn> is a generic interface type with no direct superinterfaces.
D.) The raw type C.
5.) Given a generic type declaration C<F1,...,Fn> (n > 0), the direct supertypes of the parameterized type C<R1,...,Rn> where at least one of the Ri (1 ≤ i ≤ n) is a wildcard type argument, are the direct supertypes of the parameterized type C<X1,...,Xn> which is the result of applying capture conversion to C<R1,...,Rn> (§5.1.10).

4A is applied before visitTypeArgs is called,  this happens in visitDeclared_Declared, AnnotatedTypes.castedAsSuper(subtype.atypeFactory, subtype, supertype);.   So subtype and supertype have the same underlying type in visitTypeArgs.  (The documentation of subtype and supertype was wrong; I've fixed it.)
4B is applied in visitTypeArgs in the if statement isContainedMany(subtype.getTypeArguments(), supertypeTypeArgs, covariantArgIndexes) (In your comment above you asked if this if statement was for 4C, but it's 4B.)
5 is applied in visitTypeArgs in isContainedMany(capturedSubtype.getTypeArguments(), supertypeTypeArgs, covariantArgIndexes).  As you suggest, this is an optimization, because calling isSubtype(subtype, supertype) would result in  the isContainedMany(capturedSubtype.getTypeArguments(), supertypeTypeArgs, covariantArgIndexes) call.
I've attempted to make this clearer in the code.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
Nit: the ordering of tests in this cascaded if is:
sub && super
!sub && !super && X
sub && !super
super && !sub
!sub && !super && Y
It's a bit weird to see the two cases that include "!sub && !super" separated rather than appearing together (probably at the end).
Also, it might be helpful for documentation (and won't hurt performance) to make the omitted parts of the tests explicit, as I did above.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The cascaded if statement is not exhaustive:  control can fall through.  Why is that?  It might be clearer to make the handling of the final case when haveSameDeclaration is true explicit, unless it needs all the following logic in the method.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Three lines below, a comment says "one use of the type has an annotation and the other does not", but I don't think that is possible because the previous two cases handled whenever one use has an annotation and one does not.  Can you double-check?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Are these necessarily the same captured type variable, or might they be different ones?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Can you expand on this comment?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The naming of visitTypevarSupertype and visitTypevarSubtype feels inconsistent with the rest of the class.  Usually a visit method name contains the types of its two arguments, so I expected these to be something like visitType_TypeVariable and visitTypeVariable_Type.  Can you explain the reason for the naming, or make it more consistent?  (I realize these are not overloads, but more consistency is still desirable if their names start with visit rather than, say, isSubtype.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Yes, but to clarify, wasRaw means that the underlying type is raw and the Checker Framework inferred type arguments.  The Checker Framework infers type arguments for all raw types.  wasRaw is probably a bad name.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: Could you please update the documentation of wasRaw?  Changing its name sounds like a good idea too -- that could be done in a different pull request and merged into this one.  Thanks!

timeline.bodyText:
"generic" always refers to a type declaration, which has type variables, not type arguments.
I think that "generic" here should be "parameterized".  The same comment applies to the other overload of this method.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This information would be useful in the documentation for shouldCapture.

timeline.bodyText: The notion of uninferred wildcards is not in JLS 5.1.10.  Where is a description of the variant that this method computes?  Or are uninferred wildcards always replaced by inferred wildcards before this method terminates?  (In that case, the algorithm differs from 5.1.10 but the result does not.)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Uninferred type arguments are a Checker Framework concept. They are a work around for 979.  See the comment on AnnotatedTypeMirror#containsUninferredTypeArguments().
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Maybe it would be more descriptive to name this copyNonWildcardTypeArgs or NonWildcardTypeArgCopier, which describes what it does rather than where it is used.

timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Regarding "the captured type":  I think this method applyCaptureConversion is capturing a single type, which I would call "the captured type".  Is this a mapping for the type variables of that type, rather than a mapping from whole captured types?  I may be confused, but please clarify.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
Below I've quoted two related comments that should be discussed together.

The Javadoc of TypesUtils.isCaptured says "Returns whether a TypeVariable represents a captured type." but I think it is actually whether the type variable comes from a wildcard.  The type variable is part of a captured type but is not itself a captured type.  Although javac's Type.java poorly uses the name isCaptured, I think that TypesUtils should use something more descriptive, such as isCapturedTypeVariable or isTypeVariableFromCaptureConversion or the like.


"each captured type": This method only captures one type. Are you talking about the type variables that were constructed to stand in for wildcards -- that is, any type argument that changed as a result of capture conversion? Maybe we need terminology for them, but "captured type" seems wrong. This naming choice may be related to my comment about isCaptured.

You've pointed out that I have been using "captured type" to mean both the type resulting from apply capture conversion and the "fresh" type variables created during capture conversion. Thanks, this is confusing and should be cleaned up.  I agree that it makes more sense that "captured type" means the type resulting from applying capture conversion to a type.
I was calling the type variables created during capture conversion "captured types" because:

That's what comments in the Checker Framework called them.
CapturedType is the name of the javac class that implements these type variables.
Calling toString() on a CapturedType results in something like capture#826 of ?.
In javac error messages such as:

  where CAP#1 is a fresh type-variable:
    CAP#1 extends CharSequence from capture of ? extends CharSequence

I can fix 1. 2 is an implementation detail of javac that can be ignored, but 3 and 4 are what really makes it seem like these type variables should be called "captured types" or maybe "capture types".  So, I propose calling type variables created during capture conversion "captured type variables".   (I would also rename TypesUtils.isCapture to isCapturedTypeVariable.) What do you think?  Is that still too confusing?
An alternative would be "fresh type-variable" which is used in javac error messages.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText:
I like your proposal of "captured type variable".  (I indirectly suggested in in the suggestion about isCapturedTypeVariable.)
(3 and 4 use "capture" but not "captured type", so I think they are as compatible with "captured type variable" as with "captured type".)
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The Javadoc of TypesUtils.isCaptured says "Returns whether a TypeVariable represents a captured type." but I think it is actually whether the type variable comes from a wildcard.  The type variable is part of a captured type but is not itself a captured type.  Although javac's Type.java poorly uses the name isCaptured, I think that TypesUtils should use something more descriptive, such as isCapturedTypeVariable or isTypeVariableFromCaptureConversion or the like.

timeline.bodyText: As a matter of style, I think a Map.Entry loop body is clearer when the getKey() invocation is on the first line and the getValue() invocation is on the second line.

timeline.bodyText: Since the uncaptured type is the first formal parameter, I would swap the order of this assignment and the previous one.  I think that makes the code a bit more uniform and easier to read.  I made similar changes in a number of other places in the code.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: A variable named "Mapping" or "Map" reiterates the type and thus adds no new information.  I had to keep referring back to the comments to understand uses of these variables.  Can you give them more descriptive names?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
"capturing the wildcard" is funny terminology; consider rewording, per our earlier discussion.
Also, where does the "capturing the wildcard" occur?  It would be helpful for this comment to be more explicit.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: These two lines are the same in the then clause.  Can this code be hoisted out of the if statement?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What is the relationship between typeVar.getUnderlyingType() and typeVarTypeMirror?  I'm unclear whether this is replacing a mapping or is adding a new mapping.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
If uncapturedType.getUnderlingType() is G<?, X> , and  the declaration of G is G<T, V>, then typeVar.getUnderlingType() is X and typeVarTypeMirror is V.
typeVar.getUnderlyingType() and typeVarTypeMirror can be the same.  For example if G is declared as G<T, V extends G<?, V>>, then uncapturedType could be G<?, V>, in which case both typeVar.getUnderlyingType() and typeVarTypeMirror are V.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the clarification.  I would be inclined to add a comment given that I had a question -- unless you feel that would be unhelpful clutter.

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -4631,6 +4622,447 @@ private void makeGroundTargetType( addDefaultAnnotations(functionalType); } + /** + * Return true if {@code type} should be captured. + * + *

{@code type} should be captured if all of the following are true: + * + *

    + *
  • {@code type} and {@code typeMirror} are both declared types. + *
  • {@code type} does not have an uninferred type argument and its underlying type is not + * raw. + *
  • {@code type} has a wildcard as a type argument and {@code typeMirror} has a captured type + * variable as the corresponding type argument. + *

replies.bodyText: Neither of these are true.   This method is checking if type should be captured.  If type has a wildcard as a type argument (and allow the other conditions are met), then it should be captured.  I'm not sure how to clarify the documentation.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText:
In certain parts of the code, there are application invariants about what values are passed to calls.  I was wondering if there are any here.
For example, in this method there is a specific relationship between type and typeMirror.  Since typeMirror is a capture, then the underlying type of type was capturable.  I'm wondering what that implies about type.  For example, I think it is impossible for type to be int, because its underlying type does not have a capture and because of where applyCaptureConversion is called.  (Maybe, even if that fact is true, it is an accident of the current call patterns and is not part of the specification or contract of this method.)
Or, maybe your response here is saying those two facts:

typeMirror might be a degenerate capture -- that is, it might be the underlying type itself.
this method might also perform a degenerate capture.

I hope all this clarifies my question.  Please ask again if not.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I changed the logic slightly here.  Please double-check.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This comment says "all wildcards", but there is && after uncapturedTypeArg.getKind() == TypeKind.WILDCARD.  Which is right, and why?  (When does the second conjunct have an effect?  Or should it be an assertion?)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is the key from the underlying type or from the captured type?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I don't understand this question.  Which underlying type do you mean?
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Could you document the relationship between typeVarTypeMirror and typeVar.getUnderlyingType(), and why two entries need to be added to typeVarToAnnotatedTypeArg?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What is the point of this variable?  It is only used once, on the next line.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What does this map to?  I think it's an uncaptured type argument.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This may set primary annotations as well as those on the bounds.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: There is extra logic in the initialization of typeVarUpperBound that is not present for lower bounds.  What is the reason for the difference?  (It just makes me a bit nervous to see a lack of symmetry.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Should those in the intersection also be removed from the bounds where they are now redundant?  Or is it better to retain them?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: They are expected to be on the bounds so that it is a fully-annotated type, so they should not be removed.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: Thanks.  Could you note that?
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Which AnnotatedTypeVariable is mapped to?  That is, what is its relationship to the key?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Are they already captured type variables, or does this method do the work to make them captured type variables?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Rename mappings from type parameters to type arguments.
Make changes match those in capture-conversion.

timeline.bodyText: This second sentence is a reference to a different section of the JLS.  Please mention that: "In JLS section XX, ...".
timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk: @@ -285,104 +283,101 @@ protected boolean areEqualInHierarchy( } /** - * A declared type is considered a supertype of another declared type only if all of the type - * arguments of the declared type "contain" the corresponding type arguments of the subtype. - * Containment is described in Containment is described in JLS section - * 4.5.1 "Type Arguments of Parameterized Types". + * 4.5.1 "Type Arguments of Parameterized Types". A declared type is considered a supertype of

timeline.bodyText:
I find the name of this method a bit hard to read; it sounds more like an imperative or command than a predicate.  Consider changing to "shouldIgnore..." or "isIgnored..." or the like.
Also, the Javadoc of this method says that it returns true if the checker should not issue warnings, but here it seems to affect behavior too.
timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk: @@ -285,104 +283,101 @@ protected boolean areEqualInHierarchy( } /** - * A declared type is considered a supertype of another declared type only if all of the type - * arguments of the declared type "contain" the corresponding type arguments of the subtype. - * Containment is described in Containment is described in JLS section - * 4.5.1 "Type Arguments of Parameterized Types". + * 4.5.1 "Type Arguments of Parameterized Types". A declared type is considered a supertype of + * another declared type only if all of the type arguments of the declared type "contain" the + * corresponding type arguments of the subtype. * - * @param inside a type argument of the "subtype" - * @param outside a type argument of the "supertype" + * @param inside a possibly-contained type + * @param outside a possibly-containing type * @param canBeCovariant whether or not type arguments are allowed to be covariant * @return true if inside is contained by outside, or if canBeCovariant == true and {@code inside * <: outside} */ protected boolean isContainedBy( - final AnnotatedTypeMirror inside, final AnnotatedTypeMirror outside, boolean canBeCovariant) { + AnnotatedTypeMirror inside, AnnotatedTypeMirror outside, boolean canBeCovariant) { if (ignoreUninferredTypeArgument(inside) || ignoreUninferredTypeArgument(outside)) {

replies.bodyText:
I renamed the method.

Also, the Javadoc of this method says that it returns true if the checker should not issue warnings, but here it seems to affect behavior too.

I don't understand this statement.  It does return true if the checker should not issue warnings.  In order for the checker to not issue warnings, isSubtype returns true.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: In the common case, a method either return a value or has a side effect, but not both.  I think this one does both.  Given that it does both, I think it should be documented as such, but right now it is only documented as returning a value and the side effect is not mentioned in the documenation.
replies.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I'm sorry I still don't understand your comment. What is the side effect does ignoreUninferredTypeArgument have? It doesn't change any fields.  I'm happy to fix the documentation, but I don't understand what's confusing about it.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand this line.  (I understand the one above, but I don't see why this part of the test is desirable/necessary.)  Maybe it doesn't matter because this is a hack to be removed later.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I added a comment.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure why this block is here.  Is it for case 7 in the JLS description?  Is it a hack for #979 that will be removed later?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: It's a work around.  I moved the code to make this clearer.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
There is no variable outside.  I think this comment should start with:
Let outside be ? super outsideLower extends outsideUpper.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Can there be assert outsideUpper.getKind() != TypeKind.NULL; here?  If so, add it -- for documentation more than for error detection.  If not, please explain.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Upper bounds are never TypeKind.NULL.  I could add it, but it's nonsensical.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: Ah, that is actually the NULL type, and not an indication that the source code did not contain anything.  (Since the source code can contain a lower bound, an upper bound, or neither.)  I was incorrectly reading it as the latter.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This looks suspicious to me.  Per the JLS algorithm, I think the first isSubtype call should be between outsideLower and the bound of inside, not inside itself.  (Likewise for the second isSubtype call.)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: If inside is a widlcard, then isSubtype(outsideLower, inside) calls isSubtype(outsideLower, inside.getLowerBound()) and isSubtype(inside, outsideUpper) calls isSubtype(inside.getUpperBound(), outsideUpper)
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText:
Since this is a variance from the algorithm as given in the JLS, I think it would be good to either:

change the code here (to slavishly copy the JLS algorithm) or
note that the behavior is identical to the JLS algorithm.

That will avoid a similar question by readers in the future.  Thanks.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: If subtype doesn't have any type arguments.  This method is called even if subtype doesn't have type arguments.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: A reader might expect that if subtype has no type arguments,  subtypeRaw would be true.  Is that assumption incorrect?  Could you clarify?
replies.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: subtype could be String which is neither raw nor does it have type arguments.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
The third paragraph is about comparisons between declarations (generic types).
The fourth paragraph is about comparisons between uses (parameterized types).
Should this refer to the fourth paragraph rather than the third?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Move code around to make it clear what's a work around.

timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -4240,6 +4291,202 @@ private void makeGroundTargetType( addDefaultAnnotations(functionalType); } + /** + * Return true if {@code type} should be captured. + * + *
    + *
  • {@code type} and {@code typeMirror} must both be declared types. + *
  • {@code type} must not be a raw type, must not have an uninferred type argument, and + * must have a wildcard as a type argument. + *
  • {@code typeMirror} must have a captured type as a type argument. + *

timeline.bodyText: The first and fourth disjuncts logically belong to the third bullet point in the Javadoc.  Please make this if statement be just about the second bullet point, and put the first and fourth disjuncts afterward, together with the for statement that addresses the third bullet point.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Can capturedTypeMirror be null?  It is not annotated as @Nullable.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What is the distinction between these two variables, which have the same Map type?  Does the comment apply to just one of them or to both?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please make the naming preCapturedArg and capturedTypeArg more consistent, probably by renaming preCapturedArg to preCapturedTypeArg.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Sometimes a variable named capture refers to a TypeMirror (example: captureToAnnotatedCapture).  Other times it refers to an AnnotatedTypeMirror, as here.
I think the code will be clearer to read if there is a naming convention to distinguish them.  Maybe you can use a prefix or suffix:

"a" vs ""
"a" vs "tm"
"atm" vs "tm"
maybe you can come up with a better convention.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I used "" vs "TypeMirror".  There weren't that mak
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: How is typeDeclaration modified?  (Via aliasing?)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Does this need to be public?  It feels like a helper method.
Also, I don't find the name free particularly evocative.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What is the distinction between typeArg and annoTypeArg?  Both are AnnotatedTypeMirrors.  Their names only reference their type, not their semantics or content.  Can you rename them?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This Javadoc comment isn't descriptive, especially since the next formal parameter has the same type.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: One field is named lower, but this one uses Super.  I suggest making them consistent.  I would use "lower" rather than "super".
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why is this field needed?  Can't clients just use the value of lower?  I would expect all methods to do the right thing when passed a null type (that is, a type with kind TypeKind.NULL).
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Does this need to be protected, or can it be public?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I could make it public, but there isn't much point.  Clients of DefaultTypeHierarchy access it via the interface TypeHierarchy whose only method is isSubtype.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Rather than repeating this, I would refer to isContainedBy().  You might be able to reduce the size of the previous paragraph too.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
I don't understand the logic of the next 7 lines.
One question is why there is a special case that depends on hasSuperBound.  I think that the lower bound will be the null type, and I would expect all the tests to work properly for such a type.
It would also be helpful to state the algorithm you are following.
I think it's something like this:
If Outside is not a wildcard:
  require equality
  return

if Inside is not a wildcard:
  Inside must be the appropriate one of Outside's bounds
  return

let Outside = ? super Lo extends Uo
let Inside = ? super Li extends Ui
require Ui <: Uo
        Lo <: Li

(which is itself just a simplification of the first 5 bullet points in the containment algorithm of JLS 4.5.1) plus special cases for contravariance that I have not written down.  Is the algorithm as I stated it correct or incorrect?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I cannot follow this comment.  Is glb the same as annos?  Please define "lowest bound".  (I see what it is from the code, but clarifying the intent will help to ensure that the two are consistent.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please add Javadoc to this method, which is used by your code.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why are both of these tested?  I would expect them to have the same value.  Should there be an assertion that the two boolean values are the same?
timeline.author: mernst

    + *
  • {@code type} and {@code typeMirror} must both be declared types. + *
  • {@code type} must not be a raw type, must not have an uninferred type argument, and + * must have a wildcard as a type argument. + *
  • {@code typeMirror} must have a captured type as a type argument. + *
+ * + * @param type annotated type to capture + * @param typeMirror underlying Java type + * @return true if {@code type} should be captured + */ + private boolean shouldCapture(AnnotatedTypeMirror type, TypeMirror typeMirror) { + if (!(type.getKind() == TypeKind.DECLARED && typeMirror.getKind() == TypeKind.DECLARED)) {

timeline.bodyText: Why is this size comparison necessary as part of the test?  I think that if it is true, there is some corruption.  Should you change this into an assertion?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The map's key type is TypeVariable which is a subclass of TypeMirror.  Can you be more specific than "type mirror"?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: It says "captured type mirror", not just "type mirror".
replies.author: smillst

timeline.message:
Merge remote-tracking branch 'remotes/smillst/for-loop-capture' into for-loop-capture

# Conflicts:
#	dataflow/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/dataflow/cfg/node/MethodInvocationNode.java
Merge branch 'capture-conversion' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into capture-conversion

Merge remote-tracking branch 'remotes/origin/master' into capture-conversion

# Conflicts:
#	framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/framework/type/DefaultTypeHierarchy.java
Merge branch 'for-loop-capture' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into for-loop-capture
Merge branch 'for-loop-capture' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into for-loop-capture
Throw BugInCF if impossible situation arises
Make code shorter and hopefully no less clear

timeline.bodyText: Here or in the overview documentation of BoundType, please state the object invariants.  I think that one of the two fields lower and upper is always trivial/vacuous/degenerate; that is, either the lower bound is Void/NULL, or the upper bound is Object.  It is also possible for both of those conditions to hold.  Is that correct?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is it the case that the algorithm can ignore the other bound because it is always trivial (is a Void/NULL lower bound or is an Object upper bound)?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why is the outside.hasExplicitLowerBound part of this test necessary?  If my guess about object invariants is correct, then if there is an explicit lower bound, the upper bound is Object, and the other disjunct will definitely evaluate to true.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
This logic looks wrong to me (and it differs from the last 4 lines of isContainedBy.
I think the logic should be
(canBeCovariant && isSubtype(outside.lower, insideBoundType.lower))
|| isContainedByBoundType(insideBoundType.upper, outside, canBeCovariant)
or
canBeCovariant ? isSubtype(outside.lower, insideBoundType.lower))
: isContainedByBoundType(insideBoundType.upper, outside, canBeCovariant)
Note that these two proposals are not logically equivalent.  Both express approximately:  "if canBeCovariant is true, then use isSubtype, otherwise use isContainedByBoundType."  I'm not sure which one you would want to use.  If the current code is correct, please explain it.
The same comment applies just below.
timeline.author: mernst
mernst

timeline.bodyText: Another confusing thing about this code is that it is within a test !insideBoundType.hasExplicitLowerBound and it uses outsideBoundType.lower.  If my guess about object invariants is right, then whenever hasExplicitLowerBound is false, the lower bound is Void/NULL, and there doesn't seem to be much point in doing a test against two occurrences of Void/NULL.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The following code also seems to assume that at least one of the bounds of BoundType is non-trivial.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure how this affects the result.  It changes outside's lowest bound, but the return statement on the next line uses outsideUpper which is unaffected by this method call.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is this if test an optimization to save resources compared to the return ... && ... statement on line 435, or is it logically necessary?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message:
Revert "Merge ../checker-framework-branch-master into capture-conversion"

This reverts commit 7dbcc757975605c396a89a1af26a5330ed9175c6, reversing
changes made to 37ced953b4d6601eb5787514ab2f4e43c81f8639.

Add TODOs at all the places that mention the lack of capture conversion.

Each location needs to be reviewed.

Use TypeVarSubstitutor

This can't be merged first because it crashes in master in isContainedBy.
Handle case when bounds are equal.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'remotes/origin/master' into capture-conversion

#	checker/tests/guieffect/ThrowCatchTest.java
#	checker/tests/nullness/generics/WildcardOverride.java
When building a type tree, don't recur infinitely on wildcards

Capture type arguments before checking against bounds.
Handle type variables in intersection types.
Use the captured type to get the bounds from use.
